Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.raw_text: Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.proposition: This Complaint is based on Massachusetts General Laws Ch. 186, Sec. 14, Ch. 239, Sec. 8A, as well as relevant case law including Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), and Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982), among others.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.support_reasoning: The proposition merely cites Hemingway as part of the legal basis for a complaint grounded in G.L. c. 186, § 14 and c. 239, § 8A and related case law. While this excerpt is a concurrence/dissent and not the majority, it squarely discusses G.L. c. 239, § 8A, tenants’ use of sanitary code violations as a defense to nonpayment, and the interdependence of rent and habitability obligations—core issues relevant to a complaint relying on habitability and § 8A. Thus, Hemingway is an appropriate supporting authority, even though this passage is not the binding holding itself.
Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 3.relevant_excerpt: "The answer of each tenant also ‘claims the protection of ... [G. L. c. 239, § 8A] ... That the defendant has complied with ... [c. 239, § 8A] and that therefore the plaintiff cannot recover.’ As to each tenant the trial judge found that she had failed to give the written notice required by § 8A... He then properly ruled that § 8A ‘is not available to the defendant as a defense to this proceeding.’ ... Having thus failed to qualify for the defence which would otherwise have been available to them under § 8A, the tenants ask this court to give them relief by holding (a) that the landlord impliedly warranted the fitness of their apartments for habitation..."

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: This Complaint is based on Massachusetts General Laws Ch. 186, Sec. 14, Ch. 239, Sec. 8A, as well as relevant case law including Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), and Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982), among others.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The proposition merely asserts that the complaint is based on G.L. c. 186, §14, c. 239, §8A, and relevant case law including Boston Housing Authority v. Hemingway and Simon v. Solomon. Simon v. Solomon squarely addresses and applies G.L. c. 186, §14, discusses its relationship to other tenant-remedy statutes including c. 239, §8A, and builds on Hemingway’s warranty-of-habitability framework. Thus, citing Simon v. Solomon as part of the relevant case law foundation for such a complaint is accurate and supported by the opinion.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing. See, e.g., G. L. c. 111, §§ 127A-127L, c. 186, §§ 14, 15E, 15F, 18, 19; c. 239, § 8A. These statutes are designed to facilitate enforcement of State housing regulations and to provide relief for tenants deprived of decent homes. See Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 191-193 (1973).”}
